messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Pro-rata means you get money only for the days you work.  
Basis means the way we do something.  

I worked five days every week.  
I had a baby and I stayed home.  
After that, I wanted more time with my children before school.  
I talked with my boss.  
My boss and I said I will work three days every week.  
My pay is lower now because I work only three days.  
I get paid on a pro-rata basis.  
But I still have the same work.  
I do five days of work in three days.  
But I get much less money for it.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6408 is below the required 0.75 and the BERTScore of 0.8621 is below the required 0.90, indicating significant loss of core message and key lexical details. Detected deviations:
- The MeaningBERT score of 0.6408 is too low and shows loss of the original grievance tone about unfair workload.
- The BERTScore of 0.8621 is too low and reflects omission of terms like "parental leave", "negotiating", "significant cut in my pay", and "slightest".
- The output removes the nuance of "workload hasn't decreased in the slightest" and the contrast of "five days' worth of work in three days".
Suggestion: Reintroduce explicit references to "parental leave", "negotiating with my boss", "pro-rata pay cut", and the original contrast in workload. Use simple sentences but preserve these key terms.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Pro-rata is when you get money only for the days you work.  
Basis is the way we do something.

I had a baby.  
I had parental leave.  
I wanted more time with my children before school starts.  
I negotiated with my boss.  
We agreed that I work three days every week.  
I have a big pay cut.  
This is a pro-rata pay cut.  
My workload has not decreased in the slightest.  
I do five days' worth of work in three days.  
I get much less money for it.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6971 is too low. Your version omits the contrast between a five-day workload and three-day pay and downplays the grievance tone. FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8715 is below 0.90. Key phrases like "significant cut in my pay" and "workload hasn’t decreased in the slightest" were simplified or lost emphasis.
Detected deviations:
- You defined “basis” but the original did not define it, shifting focus to definitions over content.
- You removed the emotional emphasis on unfairness and replaced it with flat statements.
- The original negotiation detail "after negotiating with my boss" became only "I negotiated with my boss"—you dropped the sequence and causal nuance.
- You failed to convey "I’m paid on a pro-rata basis" as a cause of the pay cut; you only state the pay cut exists.
- The phrase "in the slightest" lost its emphatic force.
Suggestions: Restore the phrase “significant cut in my pay” and link it directly to “pro-rata basis.” Reintroduce the original sequence “after I came out of parental leave” to preserve context. Reinsert the grievance tone by keeping “hasn’t decreased in the slightest!” and showing the unfair contrast between days worked and pay.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Pro-rata means you are paid only for the days you work.

I worked five days every week.  
I had time off when my baby was born.  
Then I came back to work.  
I wanted more time with my children.  
School will start soon.  
Then I talked to my boss.  
We agreed I work three days every week.  
This gave me a significant cut in my pay.  
I am paid on a pro-rata basis.  
But my workload has not decreased in the slightest!  
I do five days' work in three days.  
But I earn much less money for that.  
It is not fair!
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8729 is below the required 0.90.
1. The phrase "parental leave" was replaced with "time off when my baby was born", losing the original term and nuance.
2. "After negotiating with my boss" became "Then I talked to my boss", weakening the formal action.
3. An extra definition line "Pro-rata means you are paid only for the days you work" was added, which was not in the original.
Suggestion: Restore the term "parental leave". Use the exact phrase "negotiating with my boss". Remove unauthorized additions to recover lost lexical content.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: I used to work five days every week.  
Then I came back from parental leave.  
I wanted more time with my children.  
School will start soon.  
After negotiating with my boss, we agreed on my schedule.  
I work three days every week.  
I earn much less money because of this.  
I am paid on a pro-rata basis.  
Pro-rata means I earn money only for days I work.  
Basis means how we calculate money.  
Now I notice my work has not decreased.  
I do five days of work in three days.  
I earn much less money for the same work.  
It is not fair.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8734 is below the required 0.90. Key lexical details were lost or altered: the phrase "significant cut in my pay" was replaced by the vague "earn much less money," and the term "five-day week" became "five days every week," reducing fidelity. Suggestion: Restore exact key phrases from the original, e.g. use "significant cut in my pay" and retain core expressions verbatim to improve BERTScore.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: I worked a five-day week.  
Then I came back from family leave.  
I wanted more time with my children.  
School will start soon.  
I talked to my boss.  
We agreed on my schedule.  
Now I work a three-day week.

I get paid on a pro-rata basis.  
Pro-rata is a rule for pay.  
Basis is the way we use the rule.  
If I work three days, I get pay for three days.  
Now I see my work is the same.  
I do five days of work in three days.  
This is not fair.

FAIL: CEFR Compliance. Classifier rated B1. The text exceeds A2 level in multiple ways.
- The definition sentences use the verb "means" (e.g., "Pro-rata means you get pay…"). This is a B2-level definition structure, not A2.
- The noun "basis" is classified as B1 and is too abstract for A2.
- The added in-text definitions introduce complex clauses and abstract concepts, raising the level above A2.
- The term "pro-rata" originates at C1 and is not on A2 word lists.
Suggestion: Remove all in-text definitions. Replace "pro-rata basis" with a simple phrase like "pay for days you work." Use only A2 vocabulary and very short sentences. Avoid abstract nouns and definition constructions.
